anatomical location body part affected: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurological condition
description: ASD is a developmental disorder characterized by impairments in development of language, communication, and reciprocal interaction and the presence of repetitive and ritualistic behaviors.(1) Onset is before the age of three years.(2,48) The diagnostic label of ASD now includes several conditions that were previously considered separate disorders: autistic disorder, pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS),  early infantile autism, atypical autism, Kanner’s autism, high-functioning  autism, childhood disintegrative disorder, and Asperger’s syndrome (AS).(48) According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5),  all of the aforementioned conditions are referred to and diagnosed as ASD.(48) Diagnostic criteria for ASD per the DSM-5  are as follows:

Criterion A: Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts, as manifested by the following, currently or by history: –Deficits in social-emotional  reciprocity (e.g., failure to initiate social interactions; inappropriate responses to social situations)(48) –Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction (e.g., poor eye contact; lack of facial expression)(48) –Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships (e.g., difficulty making friends; no interest in one’s peers)(48) –For the diagnosis of ASD, these deficits must be pervasive and sustained(48) –In addition to documenting the presence of the above mentioned deficits, the diagnosing clinician (a specially trained developmental physician or psychologist) must also specify current severity level of social communication impairments when diagnosing ASD.(48) Because the severity of behaviors in ASD is known to fluctuate over time, the severity label is used to refer only to current severity(48)

Criterion B: Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviors, interests, or activities, as manifested by at least two of the following, currently or by history: –Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech(48) -An example of stereotyped speech is echolalia, described below(48) –Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal or nonverbal behavior (e.g., rigid thought patterns; wanting the same sequence of activities in each therapy session)(48)  –Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus (e.g., a strong preoccupation with comic books to the exclusion of all other activities and interests)(48) –Hyper-  or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment (e.g., inability to tolerate loud noises; apparent indifference to pain or temperature)(48) –In addition to documenting the presence of two or more of the above mentioned deficits, the diagnosing clinician must also specify current severity level of restrictive, repetitive behaviors when diagnosing ASD.(48) Because the severity of behaviors in ASD is known to fluctuate over time, the severity label is used to refer only to current severity(48)

Criterion C: Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period (but may not become fully manifested until social demands exceed limited capacities, or may be masked by learned strategies later in life)(48)
Criterion D: Symptoms cause clinical significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of current functioning(48)

Criterion E: These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay(48) –Intellectual disability does often co-occur  with ASD; in order for both diagnoses to be applicable, social functioning would be impaired more than would be expected given the individual’s developmental level and cognitive functioning(48)

The diagnosing clinician will also specify the following when diagnosing ASD: –With or without accompanying intellectual impairment(48) –With or without accompanying language impairment(48) –Associated with another neurodevelopmental, mental, or behavioral disorder(48) –With catatonia(48)
Severity levels in ASD(48) –Level 3 – requiring very substantial support –Level 2 – requiring substantial support –Level 1 – requiring supports

presentation signs and symptoms: Communication deficits in individuals with ASD vary greatly and depend on the severity of the disorder and any accompanying cognitive deficits. Communication has been described as "delayed," as well as "deviant," with the primary area of deficit in language pragmatics and speech prosody

The following are some common communication symptoms: –Reduced responsiveness to others’ communication (e.g., failure to respond to name)(5) –Echolalia (immediate or delayed imitation of what is heard; e.g., the child repeats the tagline from a commercial on television)(5) –Unusual word use (e.g., using made-up  words or attaching idiosyncratic meanings to words)(5) –Difficulty telling narratives (e.g., does not refer appropriately to characters in a story, errors in syntax)(5) –Difficulty with social use of language (i.e., pragmatics)(5) -Limited use of gaze to monitor conversational partner's interest and mental state -Discussion of socially inappropriate topics -Difficulty modulating conversational turn length -Poor maintenance of others' conversational topic -Poor sharing of information on topic (e.g., discourse contains too many details or irrelevant details) -Difficulty adjusting social register (e.g., overly pedantic in informal situations) -Difficulty understanding nonliteral language such as jokes, metaphors, or slang -Difficulty adjusting language for context and listener needs; difficulty with perspective taking

The following are other symptoms associated with ASD:(6) –Repetitive movements (rocking, twirling, hand-flapping) –Self-abusive  behavior (e.g., biting, head-banging) –Preference for playing alone –Difficulty taking another person’s perspective (appears unaware of others’ feelings) –Difficulty handling/adapting to disturbances in routine –Fascination with parts of an object (e.g., spinning wheels of a car) –Unusual sensitivity to light, sound, and touch  –Constant physical movement –Persons with ASD often have other conditions that interfere with their health and socialization, such as aggression, inattention, hyperactivity, and mood/anxiety symptoms(7) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Family members or caregivers might be involved in both assessment and treatment. They have a unique perspective and can provide information about the individual that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures(13)

The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning and when developing treatment goals.(13) Communication needs of the individual should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting(13)

When assessing the language and social skills of individuals with ASD, it is imperative to use appropriate contexts, content, and procedures. This may include observation of the individual in his or her typical or daily activities (e.g., employment setting)(14)

For young adults, assessment and treatment might focus on functional communication skills needed for successful transition from the educational system into the workforce.(15) The viability of various communication strategies, the type of setting and functional communication needed, and the level of available future support should be considered(15)

causes: In 2014, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that 1 in 59 children in the United Statesaged eight years was affected by ASD.(8) The overall prevalence estimates varied among the 11 different sites includedin the monitoring network from 13.1 to 29.3 per 1,000 children.(8)ASD is four times more common among males thanfemales(8)
The exact cause of ASD is unknown, but several risk factors have been identified(3) (see below)

De novo genetic mutations appear to account for 10-20%  of cases; however, concordance rate for ASD in monozygotictwins is 70-95%,  so genetic mutations cannot entirely account for the underlying cause of ASD(2,48)
pathogenesis: The onset of ASD is before the age of three years, and the pathogenesis is largely unknown.(2,4) Clinical signs of ASDdo appear to be correlated to abnormal development of the brain, including overgrowth and neural dysfunction in theprefrontal cortex.(2) ASD is a lifelong condition, but symptoms will change throughout the lifespan. Some individuals showa gradual improvement in symptoms between the ages of six and ten years, with fluctuations in adolescence and adulthood,but an overall increase in adaptive skills and communication as they mature.(9) Conversely, psychiatric disorders,such asdepression and maladaptive behaviors, can increase in adolescence and adulthood(10)

In an MRI study conducted in the United Kingdom with 14 adults with ASD and 14 typical controls, researchers found thatthe brains of the adults with ASD had significantly lower myelin content compared to the controls(71)
risk factors asd: Environmental factors (e.g., viral infection, fetal exposure to valproate, persistent exposure to heavy metals) might increasethe risk of ASD(11,48,49)

Advanced maternal age (35+; to a lesser extent than advanced paternal age)(12,50)–In a study conducted in Finland in which researchers obtained data from the Finnish Prenatal Study of Autism and AutismSpectrum Disorders (FIPS-A),  teenage motherhood (age 19 or less) was associated with higher rates of ASD(50)

overall contraindications precautions: ASD is usually diagnosed in very young children and is a lifelong condition.(9)Communication priorities of the individual and family will change as the individual reaches adulthood. It is important to consult with the individual and family before assessment to determine the primary concerns regarding speech and language

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when ASD was diagnosed and by whom? When were communication difficulties first noted?(1) -Absence of babbling by the age of one year -No single words by age 16 months; no two-word phrases by the age of two years -Deficits in verbal and motor imitation -Lack of response to name and overall lack of social responsiveness; limited use of eye gaze and smiles -Initial development of language and social skills and then sudden loss of language and social skills -Poor social contact -Restricted use of communicative functions -Repetitive play; lining up of objects (e.g., toy cars) -Inability to make friends, inability or impaired ability to initiate conversation, lack of imaginative play, stereotyped and repetitive use of language, obsession with certain objects or subjects, unusual play with objects, and lack of flexibility/ strong adherence to routine -Authors of a large (N = 644), prospective, longitudinal study conducted in Australia found an inverse relationship between expressive vocabulary size at age two and presence of autistic behaviors at age 20. Additionally, there was a significant association between “late-talker”  status at age two and having high levels of autistic characteristics at age 20(73) -Poor conversational skills(16) -Difficulty initiating and maintaining topic(16) -Inability to interpret nonverbal communication(16) -Difficulty with perspective taking(17) -Difficulty with executive function tasks, such as prospective memory (i.e., remembering to perform a planned action at a specific time; e.g., remembering to return a rented movie), organization, planning, and goal completion(18) -Reduced eye contact in social situations; averted eye gaze(19)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary according to the individual’s presenting symptoms
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they beingSSRIs are antidepressants that are also used to treat obsessivecompulsive  behaviors and anxiety(11)Tricyclics are antidepressants also used to treat obsessive-compulsive  behaviors(11)These drugs are used to reduce stereotyped behaviors, decrease hyperactivity, and minimize aggression(11)Stimulants may be used to decrease hyperactivity in individuals with ASD(11)Anti-anxiety  drugs can help to reduce anxiety and panic disorders associated with ASD(11)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  When ASD is suspected, a physician or other qualified health care professional will administer a screening. If the screening indicates the possible presence of ASD, a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation should be conducted by a multidisciplinary team (e.g., psychologist, neurologist, psychiatrist, SLP). In addition, an audiologist can test for hearing impairment(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, special diets) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether individual has had occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions, and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Does the individual have hearing or vision difficulties? -How severe are the individual's communication difficulties? -Does the individual have a co-occurring  disorder associated with ASD, such as an intellectual disability, Down syndrome, epilepsy, or tuberous sclerosis?(11) -Does the individual or a caregiver speak another language at home? -What modality does the individual use to communicate? -Is the individual overly sensitive to sensory stimulation? -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 772 total participants, researchers found that sensory processing abnormalities were common among individuals with an Autism Quotient (AQ) score above 32 points (the typically used screening cut-off  score for this measure). Within this sample, 45 participants had scores above 32 points, but only 23 reported a clinical diagnosis of ASD. Researchers administered three different sensory processing scales to all participants and found significantly more sensory processing abnormalities among those with AQ scores above 32(70) -In another study conducted in the United Kingdom with 221 adults with ASD and 181 adults without ASD, individuals with ASD reported significantly more sensory over-responsivity  to daily sensory stimuli than those without ASD in an online survey.(64) Survey questions inquired about visual, auditory, tactile, olfactory, gustatory, and proprioceptive stimuli(64) -How does the individual respond to loud noises/visually stimulating environments/being in a group of people? -How does the individual handle changes in his or her routine? -Does the individual have any challenging behaviors (e.g., throwing, hitting, self-injury)? -Does the individual have anxiety associated with communication? Anxiety often worsens in adolescence and adulthood as the individual becomes more aware of interpersonal difficulties(20)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -How does the individual communicate (e.g., oral language, sign language, manual gestures, vocalizations, body language)? -How well does the individual understand spoken communication? -How well does the individual use oral communication? -How does the individual communicate when he/she is upset or anxious?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the individual is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could indicate the need for a physician or social worker referral (e.g., anxiety, seizures, difficulty sleeping)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory history and current respiratory status for any indication of aspirationDocument psychosocial status and whether the patient is under the care of a mental health professional -Approximately 70% of individuals with ASD have at least one comorbid psychiatric disorder; 40% have two or more comorbid psychiatric disorders(48) -Individuals with ASD often have other conditions that interfere with their health and socialization, such as aggression, inattention, hyperactivity, and mood/anxiety symptoms(7) -Adults with ASD have a higher incidence of social anxiety, depression, and aggression than the general population.(21,51,52,56,57)As an individual with ASD ages and attempts to integrate into society (e.g., attend college, maintain a job), psychosocial problems can worsen due to the lack of social acceptance(21) -Problems with social skills might arise from an underlying inability to perceive facial features and expressions in the same manner as typically developing individuals(22)  -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers used data from the National Longitudinal Transition Study-2 and compared the social experiences of 660 young adults with an ASD to those of other individuals with diagnoses of intellectual disability, emotional disturbance, and learning disabilities. Researchers reported that the young adults with ASD were significantly more likely to never see friends, never get called by friends, never be invited to activities, and be socially isolated than the young adults with other diagnoses. Lower conversation ability, lower functional skills, and living with a parent were predictors of less social participation in the young adults with ASD(60)Document hearing abilities; review reports from audiology if available(1) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of developmental delay in any area?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient or patient’s family about other problems (e.g., intellectual disability, epilepsy, hearing loss, visual impairment)(69) In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found that it was possible to identify which individuals were most at risk for intellectual disability as adults with verbal and nonverbal intelligence testing at age two or three years. Additionally, researchers found that participation in earlyintervention  programs at ages two and three years resulted in very positive outcomes for individuals with ASD who were considered cognitively able(63)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs). Inquire of a pharmacist or a physician about medications that influence eating, appetite, sleep habits, mood, or gastrointestinal status
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient or patient’s family about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Things to consider receive intervention services? If so, are they home or clinic based? Does the individual attend school? Does the individual work, volunteer, or attend a sheltered workshop? -Attainment and maintenance of employment is a common goal for adults with ASD and their families. Having a job allows an individual to have increased financial independence and social interactions, and has been found to improve quality of life, self-esteem,  and cognitive abilities in adults with ASD. In the United States, vocational rehabilitation services are available to individuals with disabilities but have been found to be underutilized by adults with ASD.(72) Provide a referral for vocational rehabilitation services when appropriate -In a study conducted in the United States with 153 adults with ASD, researchers investigated the relationship between behavioral functioning (ASD symptoms, maladaptive behaviors, activities of daily living [ADLs]) and the vocational/ educational activities of these adults.(66) The average age of the participants was 30.2 years, and researchers collected data on behavioral functioning and vocational/educational activities twice, five and a half years apart. Researchers found that higher levels of vocational independence and engagement were associated with improved behavioral functioning (reduced symptoms of ASD, reduced maladaptive behaviors, and improvements in ADLs); however, these associations were not statistically significant(66)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Obtain information on adaptive behaviors and adaptive equipment the individual is using, such as augmentative or alternative communication (AAC) devices, hearing aids, glasses, or adaptive eating equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: What setting is the home environment supervised apartment, independent living situation? Identify any barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -What form of transportation (e.g., driving, public transportation, family/friends’ cars) does that patient use to get around (e.g., to work, therapy, school)? In a study conducted in the United States with ten males with ASD (ages 18-24  years), researchers found that participants performed comparably to an age-matched  control group using a driving simulator under normal conditions.(58) Researchers did find that the participants with ASD exhibited certain patterns that were  suboptimal with respect to driving safety (e.g., shifting visual attention away from the forward roadway in response to increased cognitive demand during a cell phone task), which warrants further research regarding driving safety of adults with ASD(58)

relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Individuals with ASD might communicate by use of differentoral language, gestures, sign language, vocalizations, body language, or AAC. A communication assessment should be appropriate to the skills of the individual and assess all modes of communication that are usedSpeech development in individuals with ASD is usually commensurate with mental age. If the individual uses speech for communication and if there are concerns about speech/articulation ability, a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis can be used to determine errors that have a high frequency of occurrence, as well as those that are functionally important for the individual. A sound inventory can be completed for those who have severely limited speech. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be calculated. Determine if the individual uses any irregular prosody patterns (e.g., abnormal rate or loudness levels) and if these irregularities interfere with social interaction or intelligibilityLanguage assessment should include a combination of formal and informal measures (e.g., language samples, observations) to assess syntax, semantics, and pragmatics. Syntax and semantic abilities usually correspond with mental age, and pragmatic ability is usually the most impaired in individuals with ASD. Informal language measures are(29)Videotaped language samples are useful for examining the individual’s pragmatic skills, such as responsiveness to communication, ability to interpret a conversational partner's intent, ability to retell a narrative or past experience, metalinguistic skills, and ability to maintain topic.(29) Language samples can also assess word use/ vocabulary, presence of echolalia, use of nonverbal communication, and syntactic elements, such as pronoun use. Prompts for a conversational sample include "Tell me about your family," "Tell me about work," and "Tell me what you do when you're not at work." When possible, observe the individual's language in a daily situation, such as the workplaceThere are no comprehensive formal language measures that have been standardized for adults with ASD. Test administration may need to be adapted and standardized scores should be interpreted with(30) A standardized measure of receptive vocabulary for ages two years, six months to 90+ years(31) A individually administered, norm-referenced  test designed to assess listening comprehension and oral expression for ages three to 21 years(32) A norm-referenced,  individually administered expressive and receptive language assessment for ages three to 21 years. Contains a subtest to measure pragmatic language skills (the Pragmatic Judgment subtest)Examine the situations in which the individual uses language. A structured work setting may provide limited opportunities for the individual to initiate communication or engage in reciprocal(5)(34) A caregiver-rating  scale for social and communicative behaviors, such as social awareness, social information processing, ability to produce reciprocal social responses, and social use of language. It can be used in children and adolescents (four to 18 years)(35) A checklist of pragmatic skills based on observation(36) A measure that provides an inventory of an individual’s communication abilities for ages three through adulthood(37) Measures higher-level  language functions, such as making inferences, listening comprehension, and figurative language. Level 2 can provides normative information for ages ten through 18 yearsProvide a voice evaluation if there is indication of a voice disorder -For detailed information on assessment of the vocal mechanism and voice disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicProvide a fluency evaluation if there is indication of a fluency disorder  -For detailed information on assessment of fluency disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on stutteringProvide an evaluation of reading and writing as necessary. An evaluation of written language may be necessary for an AAC assessment. Assessment can include letter identification, letter-sound identification, phonological awareness skills, site word reading, fluency, and reading comprehension. There are no reading assessments that have been standardized for adults with ASD; adaptations may be necessary for administration and results should be interpreted with caution(33)
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess the individual's oral motor skills during speech, imitation of motor movements, diadochokinesis tasks, and strength testing tasks in order to identify or rule out a motor-based speech-language disorder
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: If present, cognitive deficits associated with ASD can range from mild to profound. The evaluating or treating SLP should note the results of any neurological (MRI, CT), neuropsychological, psychological/cognitive, or adaptive behavior tests that have been completed –In a study conducted in Germany with 30 individuals with ASD, aged 14-33  years, researchers found that, compared to age-matched  controls, the individuals with ASD exhibited impaired spatial working memory and visuo-motor  information processing abilities but no explicit impairments of planning, cognitive flexibility, or cognitive inhibition(55) –Authors of a meta-analysis  that included 37 studies investigating verbal or visual mentalizing abilities in adults with ASD or schizophrenia, researchers found that all of these adults exhibited significant impairments of mentalizing abilities.(65)Mentalizing is a term that refers to the human ability to understand the desires, needs, feelings, reasons, and beliefs of ourselves and others. For typical adults, mentalizing happens automatically; when encountering another person, a typical adult will understand that person’s behavior within the context of the person’s thoughts and feelings. For example, if a cashier is abrupt and hurried at the store, a typical adult might look at the clock and realize the store actually closed five minutes early and this cashier would probably like to go home on time. For an adult with ASD, authors of the meta-analysis  reported that despite visual and verbal information, these adults have difficulty mentalizing and processing these cues(65)(23) Ages 16 years to 90 years, 11 months -In a study of adults conducted in the United States with ASD, researchers found that compared to typically developing adults, individuals with high-functioning  ASD had lower scores on all cognitive domains of the WAIS-IV  with the most significant differences in the measures of verbal comprehension and processing speed(24)(25) An assessment of self-sufficiency  across the lifespan, thecommunication skills, daily living skills, socialization skills, and motor skills from birth to age 90 years
relevant tests and measures.aac assessment: Individuals with ASD sometimes require the use of AAC. AAC can be aided or unaided. Aided AAC requires external equipment, such as picture books/cards, communication boards, or computerized speech-generating  devices. Unaided AAC refers to communication techniques that the person can produce without external resources, such as manual signs, gestures, and facial expressions.(26) Many individuals with ASD use both types, and AAC can be used in addition to oral language. Authors of a systematic review of AAC for adults and adolescents with ASD found that AAC is beneficial for these individuals; however, the research is limited and most studies focus on AAC that is used for the communicative function of requesting.(75) Additional research on the effectiveness of AAC for adults with ASD for a greater variety of communicative functions (e.g., social communication).(75) Adults with ASD who use AAC to communicate often have multiple disabilities, including intellectual disability and physical or sensory (e.g., visual) impairments.(69) It is important that AAC be tailored to each individual’s abilities and disabilities.(69)The most appropriate model for this assessment is a team assessment with participation and input from family members.(27) Adults with ASD can benefit significantly from the use of AAC to communicate with their aging parents.(28) Universal design is a relatively new concept with respect to assistive technology, including AAC; the idea of universal design is to create devices that serve the needs of a wide range of individuals—those with and without disabilities.(62) For example, there are many apps available for download on the Apple iPad that allow it to become a high-tech AAC device for an individual with ASD, but it can also be used by the individual’s parents, peers, caregivers, or employers whose language abilities are intact.(61) For devices with universal design, no adaptations are necessary.(62) The iPad and other commercially available computer tablets also have the advantage of being highly socially acceptable, which is appealing to many people because the AAC device does not –What type of AAC does the individual use? –Is he or she comfortable with the AAC being used? –How long has the individual used AAC? –Does AAC improve communicative efforts both receptively and expressively?  –The SLP and communication assessment team should always consider the cultural, linguistic, and economic background of the family during assessment and when making recommendations regarding AAC use(26) –For detailed information on assessment for AAC for individuals with ASD, as well as information about treatment utilizing AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Feeding difficulties associated with ASD include strong food preferences, restriction of diet to a narrow range of foods, unusual eating behaviors (e.g., eating inedible items), and oral motor difficulties.(38) In addition to a behavioral component to feeding, physiological issues, such as sensory processing issues and gastrointestinal issues, might also play a role in the feeding abilities of individuals with ASD.(38) For detailed information on assessment and treatmentAutism Spectrum Disorder ; CINAHLT708946

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Individuals with ASD may be at risk for feeding and swallowing disorders; perform a feeding/swallowing evaluation if feeding/swallowing disorders are suspected or if the individual exhibits signs of malnourishment
High levels of parent/caregiver stress due to behavior problems associated ASD may require referral to clinical/counseling/ support services for families/caregivers(39)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A comprehensive speech-language evaluation in addition to patient and family interviews and the reason for the initial referral will determine the need for treatment and treatment goals. For adult patients, goals might be related to personal empowerment, increased community access, increased independence, and vocational needs(33)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Hearing loss Rett syndrome(48) Schizophrenia with childhood onset(48) Intellectual disability with behavioral symptoms(48) Receptive language disorder(48) Psychosocial/environmental deprivation Disintegrative psychoses Selective mutism(48) Social (pragmatic) communication disorder(48) Stereotypic movement disorder(48) Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)(48)
prognosis: In a longitudinal study conducted in the United Kingdom with 58 individuals with ASD, researchers investigated which factors affected real-life  outcomes in adulthood.(53) Researchers found that the presence of challenging behaviors (as measured by the Childhood Behaviour Checklist [CBCL]) in adolescence was strongly predictive of dysfunction across multiple domains in young adulthood(53)

In a study conducted in the United States, researchers conducted a secondary data analysis of the National Longitudinal Transition Study-2  longitudinal data set to determine what factors were important in obtaining paid employment for 4,167 individuals with ASD who were leaving high school.(54) Researchers reported the following: –Annual household income and parental education were significantly associated with obtaining paid employment after high school for students with ASD.(54) Annual household income had the largest effect of any factor on the odds of participation in post-high  school employment; hence, researchers recommended that clinicians be aware of family needs, and provide additional support and resources to those children with ASD from low-income  families who are transitioning from high school to the job market(54) –With respect to student-related  factors, the absence of intellectual disability, having a high school diploma, the presence of adequate social skills, having received career counseling in high school, and being female were all significantly associated with postsecondary employment for individuals with ASD who are leaving high school(54)
Supported employment and job training programs are effective for assisting adults with ASD in finding and maintaining employment(67,68)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to a behavioral psychologist or behavioral specialist may be warranted to assist with challenging behaviors. Refer to a nutritionist if food preferences and mealtime aversions interfere with nutritional intake. Refer to an occupational therapist for a sensory processing and ADL assessment.(38) Social services can assist the family in negotiating assistance systems (e.g., medical services, daycare), as well as possibly finding appropriate employment if this is a goal for the patient
treatment summary: Treatment approaches –Applied behavior analysis (ABA): ABA is based on the theory of operant conditioning and is designed to eliminate negative behaviors and increase positive ones. Operant conditioning principles include shaping (reinforcing increasingly accurate versions of desired responses), chaining (reinforcing individual responses in a sequence to form a complex behavior), and discrimination training (teaching the individual to perform a behavior when one antecedent is presented and not when another is presented). Therapy is usually provided in a one-to-one  discrete trial format, and targets can include a variety of communicative functions, including preverbal communication, requesting desired items, social language (e.g., please, thank you), positive interactions with peers, answering wh-questions, and overall increased communication.(40) The administration of ABA requires specific training. For more information, see research and guidelines by Lovaas(42) –Gentle teaching: Gentle teaching incorporates many of the principles of ABA, including extinction, fading, reinforcement, and errorless learning; however, it has been described as emphasizing the nurturing relationship between the therapist and the individual with ASD(41) –Functional communication training (FCT): The method of FCT is to determine the motivation for or purpose of a challenging behavior and then teach a more appropriate replacement behavior. This approach is often used with individuals with ASD who exhibit challenging behaviors (e.g., tantrums, aggression, self-injury).  Most of the research on FCT is limited to single-subject  studies, but there is preliminary evidence that FCT is effective in eliminating negative behaviors and generalization of new language skills to other people and environments(43) –Environmental modifications: The purpose of environmental modifications is to provide the individual with increased opportunities to communicate, as well as promote communication development and/or literacy learning. Environmental modifications may include picture schedules, picture prompts, and elimination of visual distractions  –Video modeling -The purpose of video modeling is to teach an individual with ASD a particular communication skill through observational learning. The video format is intended to decrease the anxiety that might be associated with direct therapy. Video modeling has been found to be helpful for teaching vocational skills to adults with ASD(74) -Steps in the video modeling approach(43) -Videotaped images are made of a target behavior or skill -The individual watches the video clips -After viewing the clips, the individual practices the skills with a therapist -The individual then practices the skill in other settings to provide for generalization -The individual observes the video again as necessary –Social skills interventions: Social skills interventions include social skills training, the use of social stories and cognitive behavioral training: -Social skills training -In social skills training, individuals are taught skills, such as perspective taking, conversational skills, problem solving, emotional awareness, and regulation -Methods used include coaching, modeling, role plays, social scripts, feedback, and written cueing in individual or group therapy -In a study conducted in the United States of four college students with ASD and cognitive difficulties, researchers investigated the effectiveness of a program targeting social skills (primarily perspective taking in social interactions), voice, and speech during an eight-week  intervention program (sessions two times per week).(29) One subtest of the CASL (the Pragmatic Judgment subtest) was administered before and after intervention. V oice and speech goals were targeted in individual sessions but were not specifically described in the study. Social skills were targeted in group sessions in which participants took turns playing themselves and the role of another person. At the end of eight weeks, three of the four students showed significant improvement in the raw score of the Pragmatic Judgment subtest of the CASL -In a quasi-experimental  study conducted in the United States, researchers examined the feasibility and effects of a cognitive behavioral intervention on social-cognitive  functioning in adults with high-functioning  ASD.(44) The intervention group (n = 6) received therapy targeting components of social cognition, including emotion recognition in themselves and others, and social interaction skills; a control group (n = 5) received other interventions, including individual therapy and job skills coaching. Intervention was conducted over an 18-week  period, once a week in 50-minute  sessions. Participants in the intervention group showed significant improvement in theory-of-mind  skills and improvement in social communication skills; the control group did not show these improvements -Authors of a review of the literature on the effects of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for adults with ASD aiming to reduce comorbid psychiatric symptoms and increase social and communication skills found that the results of the studies reviewed were mixed, with no definitive evidence supporting the use of CBT with this population. Review authors reported that there is a need for increased quantitative research regarding the effects of CBT on adults with ASD in order to make more substantial conclusions regarding efficacy(59) -Interventions to improve executive functioning: Picture schedules, video prompting, and personal digital assistants (PDAs) have been used to assist individuals with ASD in initiating and completing tasks -AAC -Many adults with ASD do not develop oral language to meet their daily communication needs and may benefit from augmented language input to increase their language comprehension, as well as from use of AAC to express themselves(33) -Unaided approaches to AAC involve using one’s body to communicate by means of manual signs, gestures, vocalizations, facial expressions, or body movements(45) -Aided communication approaches include "light"-technology  devices and high-technology devices. Light-technology AAC refers to nonelectronic external devices such as alphabet boards, symbol-based  topic boards, dry erase boards, and programs such as the Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS). High-technology systems are electronic devices, such as speech-generating  devices (SGDs)(46) -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers investigated the effectiveness of a communication and literacy program (CALI) in improving functional communication and literacy skills in five adults (22-35  years) with ASD and cognitive difficulties working in a sheltered workshop.(33) CALI focuses on increasing the  participants' community access, empowerment, and independence. Baseline measures included formal and informal assessment of reading skills, such as phonemic awareness, letter-sound  correspondence, word identification, and text comprehension. Observations of the sheltered workshop setting assessed the extent of communication supports at baseline. Findings revealed that the individuals with ASD worked in isolation for much of the day and had little control over scheduled activities. In addition, they had little opportunity to engage in reciprocal communicative interactions and limited engagement in literacy-related  activities. CALI was delivered in individual sessions two hours a week with communication and literacy activities continuing throughout the day. Three adults participated for two years while the other participants discontinued after a shorter period due to scheduling conflicts. The program contained four major components: 1) modification of the environment to provide communication support (e.g., choice boards, picture displays/schedules) and literacy support in the form of a literacy center in which print materials were made available to participants in their free time; 2) theme-based  intervention to promote functional communication with AAC; 3) literacy skill development (e.g., guided reading, self-selected reading, word study, and writing); and 4) transfer of communication skills to a community setting by use of field trips. The researchers reported measurable gains in communicative competence for all five participants, as well as transfer of gains to the community setting -For detailed information on treatment of individuals with ASD utilizing AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic .
